item.title: 4-H Electronics Projects Archive
item.author: Nathan Petersen
item.description: History Growing up, I was a member of the All-School 4-H Club. While a member, I didn’t really appreciate the experience; it seemed like a waste of time but looking back, a few aspects come to mind as helpful. I took electronics projects for many years, from 2006 through 2011, and learned a lot. Each year, I created a display board to show at the county project exposition. The display board showcased a simple circuit that demonstrated a specific electronics principle.

item.title: Bluetooth Controlled LED Display
item.author: Nathan Petersen
item.description: Colorful display made from serially addressable LEDs for 4-H project.

item.title: Picasa Photo Gallery in PHP
item.author: Nathan Petersen
item.description: Background My earliest memories involve taking and cherishing family photos. Most of the photos I have and remember are stored in physical picture albums around my house. Since I was young, I can remember the process of my parents taking lots of pictures, developing the film, and organizing them into a multitude of albums and scrapbooks to save for memories. This system worked great for them and their parents, but I immediately saw flaws.

item.title: 4-H Electronics Project 2011
item.author: Nathan Petersen
item.description: A stereo audio amplifier for powering bookshelf speakers" A stereo audio amplifier for powering bookshelf speakers This post is one of a six part series documenting and archiving Nathan’s electronic projects created during his years participating in 4-H. To be clear, this project was done many years ago. During the winter months of 2017-2018, Nathan decided to archive his past projects as a way to remember and share them, hoping to inspire other beginning electronic hobbyists.
